topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open on why most pitches are wrong ("arrogant doctor") and the alternative movie-like structure based on a shift from an old game to a new game. Lenny introduces Andy Raskin and frames the episode around strategic narrative as an alignment tool across go-to-market and product.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Coda and Lennysjobs.com/talent.

topics.title: Andy’s origin story: failing pitch to story craft
topics.summary: Andy shares how a brutal VC rejection pushed him to study screenwriting books, realize structure matters, and rework his startup pitch to get traction and a term sheet. He explains how this eventually became his consulting focus despite initial skepticism that CEOs would pay for “story.”

topics.title: Writing and solving your own problem
topics.summary: They discuss how career opportunities often emerge from solving personal problems and sharing learnings publicly. Lenny and Andy compare “overnight success” perceptions vs. long build-up.

topics.title: What a strategic narrative is
topics.summary: Andy defines strategic narrative as the single CEO-level story that becomes a strategic north star across marketing, sales, product, fundraising, and recruiting. He contrasts the “problem-solution” pitch with a movement narrative anchored in a world shift.

topics.title: Salesforce example: old game vs new game
topics.summary: They unpack how Salesforce could have competed on feature comparisons but instead reframed the market as a paradigm shift to the cloud. Andy explains how this move reclassifies incumbents as “old game” players and invites buyers into the new rules.

topics.title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
topics.summary: Andy shares Zuora’s “subscription economy” narrative and Gong’s “goodbye opinions, hello reality” narrative. They discuss how Gong’s story elevated it from a sales ops tool to a sales leadership platform and acted as a growth multiplier.

topics.title: Impact of Andy’s viral Zuora sales deck post
topics.summary: Andy explains how “The Greatest Sales Deck I’ve Ever Seen” drove massive reach and inbound demand, proving CEOs would budget for narrative work. They broaden into the power of writing platforms (Medium/LinkedIn) and the role of editors vs direct distribution.

topics.title: Consistency vs viral hits in writing
topics.summary: They compare two content growth paths: consistent publishing vs breakout posts, with Andy noting his “boom” came after dozens of pieces and iterative traction. Andy shares why he avoids newsletters due to deadline pressure.

topics.title: Strategic narrative framework: five core parts
topics.summary: Andy lays out the structure: name the old/new game shift, name the stakes (winners/losers), name the object of the new game (rallying cry), surface obstacles, then present “magic gifts” (your solution) to overcome them. He emphasizes concise naming and emotional stakes (Star Wars analogy).

topics.title: Hero’s journey: useful but not the focus
topics.summary: They discuss parallels to the hero’s journey while Andy explains why he avoids the abstract framing in practice. He clarifies he’s not teaching generic storytelling skills but crafting one strategic story that turns the buyer into the hero.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Eco, then Lenny transitions back to applying the framework with a concrete company example.

topics.title: Case study: 360Learning narrative rebuild
topics.summary: They walk through 360Learning’s shift from a flat “collaborative learning” pitch to a story about moving from top-down training to “upskill from within,” using winner examples and high stakes. Andy explains how this reframing reduced competitive comparison questions and sped up executive buy-in.

topics.title: Business impact: marketing and product alignment
topics.summary: Andy describes outcomes he hears from CEOs: selling a movement rather than features, generating non-salesy thought leadership content, and using the narrative as a product roadmap filter for feature requests. Examples include Zuora’s content engine and Gong’s refusal to build “opinion” features.

topics.title: Strong narrative example: Drift’s conversational marketing
topics.summary: Andy highlights Drift’s “world of forms/later” to “world of now” framing as a movement that differentiated them from many similar chatbots. The narrative created a new lens for buyer expectations and urgency.

topics.title: Category creation vs movement narrative
topics.summary: Andy argues category naming is often overemphasized compared to the underlying narrative that makes a category meaningful. He positions strategic narrative as primary, with category as optional shorthand, citing Gong and HubSpot as examples where story mattered more than labels.

topics.title: Where strategic narrative fits best
topics.summary: Andy explains the framework is most powerful for B2B enterprise tech with complex products, group buying, and fast-changing feature sets. He notes it’s less applicable to many consumer products where spec comparison still dominates.

topics.title: When you need a narrative: scaling, expansion, pivots
topics.summary: Andy shares common triggers for CEOs seeking help: moving beyond founder-led “brute force” selling (often around Series B), expanding into multiple product lines requiring a bigger story, or pivoting due to market change. The narrative becomes a mechanism for consistent decision-making and communication.

topics.title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
topics.summary: Andy recommends drafting the structure and testing it quickly in real sales conversations, looking for prospects to engage with the shift and stakes. He cautions against copying slide templates (even Zuora’s) because each narrative must be tailored; he prefers iterative validation over polished rollouts.
